answers.author: Lawrence Di Re
answers.text:
Those are all very good approaches.  Why is the City not satisfied with the current practices?  What sort of employee engagement are you hoping to develop?  If you notice that employees of particular departments seem less informed or engaged than employees in general (keep in mind that being involved in the budget process is not everyone's idea of a good time), maybe those particular department heads need to open up communication lines within their own areas.  Just some thoughts, but looks like your current program is a quality approach.

answers.author: Andrew Morris
answers.text:
Your approach is much more comprehensive than ours.  In March, I meet seperately with all of the employee units to discuss the budget challanges and encourage them to make observations and ask questions that are not necessarily budget related.  Some of their comments are nicer than others, but it has been useful.  My sense is the employees like the face to face visits.  Am wondering if providing a document might be useful.

author: Anne Bradley
text: We (City of Olathe, KS) are looking for new ways to engage employees in the annual budget process. Current and recent efforts include open lunch and learn sessions during budget season, weekly "Budget News" briefs to our frequent contacts, posts to our intra-net site and review of our Budget-in-Brief document at New Employee Orientation. If your community uses another outreach effort or if you have an idea you haven't yet treid we would love to hear about it!  Thanks!
title: Engaging employees in the annual budget process
